seasonal_notes.peak_season: Summer months (June-September) when yellowfin tuna follow warm water currents closer to Hawaiian waters. Peak catches typically occur during calm weather periods.
seasonal_notes.low_season: Winter months (December-February) when cooler water temperatures drive yellowfin further offshore. Limited fishing due to rough weather conditions.
seasonal_notes.transition_periods: Spring and fall show moderate activity with variable catch rates depending on ocean temperature patterns.

seasonal_notes.peak_season: Spring (April-May) and fall (October-November) when bigeye tuna prefer the transitional water temperatures around Hawaii.
seasonal_notes.low_season: Summer months (July-September) when water temperatures are too warm for bigeye tuna, causing them to move to deeper or more northerly waters.
seasonal_notes.transition_periods: Winter months show steady but lower activity levels.

seasonal_notes.peak_season: Spring (March-May) and early fall (September-October) when mahi-mahi follow schools of flying fish and other prey closer to shore.
seasonal_notes.low_season: Winter (December-January) and mid-summer (June-July) when prey species are less abundant near Hawaiian waters.
seasonal_notes.transition_periods: Late summer shows recovery as juvenile fish mature and feeding activity increases.

seasonal_notes.peak_season: Winter and early spring (January-March, November-December) when opah prefer cooler water temperatures around Hawaii.
seasonal_notes.low_season: Summer months (June-August) when opah move to deeper or more northerly waters to find their preferred temperature range.
seasonal_notes.transition_periods: Late spring and early fall show moderate catch rates as opah move through Hawaiian waters.

seasonal_notes.peak_season: Summer months (June-September) when blue marlin are most active in warm Hawaiian waters. Peak tournament season with highest catch rates.
seasonal_notes.low_season: Winter months (December-March) when marlin activity is minimal due to cooler water temperatures and rougher sea conditions.
seasonal_notes.transition_periods: Spring shows increasing activity as waters warm, while fall sees declining activity as temperatures cool.

el_nino_years.description: El Niño conditions typically bring warmer water temperatures to Hawaii, extending the seasons for warm-water species like yellowfin tuna and marlin, while reducing catches of cooler-water species like bigeye tuna and opah.

la_nina_years.description: La Niña conditions bring cooler water temperatures, favoring species like bigeye tuna and opah while reducing warm-water species catches.

trade_wind_patterns.description: Strong trade winds affect fishing conditions and fish distribution. Consistent trades improve fishing for most species by creating upwelling and concentrating baitfish.

tropical_cyclone_season.description: Hurricane season (June-November) can significantly disrupt fishing patterns. Storms reduce fishing days but can also concentrate fish in certain areas post-storm.
